p: In the next series of experiments, the tracheal rings were treated with S. raeseri extract after their muscle was precontracted by carbachol (also known carbamylcholine, CCh), high (80 mM) K +, respectively ( Figure 2). The cumulative concentration of the S. raeseri extract (0.3–2 mg/mL) significantly reduced high CCh- and K +-evoked tracheal contraction in a concentration-dependent manner. Specifically, the cotreatment of rabbit tracheal rings with CCh and S. raeseri extract resulted in significant decrease in the muscle contraction effect in rabbits as compared with CCh alone, reaching the statistical significance at 0.5 mg/mL of the S. raeseri extract ( n = 5) ( Figure 2(a)). The S. raeseri extract-induced relaxant effect was more pronounced in higher S. raeseri extract concentrations precontracted with CCh.
